instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
Hi there,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that suddenly went out.

Magsafe turns green, then orange, but MB has no fanspin.

An inspection under the microscope showed no corrosion, but the board was very dusty.

I am using a cut off original Magsafe cable connected to my DC power supply.

I am a noob in MacBook repair, but I have experience in repairing iPhones and reading schematics. 

What I have tried so far:

I went through this diagram: [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php?title=File:G3_-_S3_Ivy_Bridge_-_Broadwell.drawio.png[/URL]

All seems to be right, until here.

[ATTACH type="full" width="521px"]60234[/ATTACH]

Many thanks in advance,
Dom

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> cycling, or just pulsing 1-2 times when connect charger?
The S0 voltages controlled by it, should also pulse; check that.

Check if board stays on in SMC bypass.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
I have checked <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> now. It's cycling every 4.2 second up to 3.44 volt.

SMC bypass seems not to be working.
I've tried to shorten <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to GND while plugging charger in and hold it for about 5 - 10 seconds. no fanspin.

[ATTACH type="full" width="360px" alt="NewFile1.jpg"]60235[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
Check for pulse at all big coils.
Also check output rails from pages 57/58.
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing too?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
[B]Check for pulse at all big coils.[/B]
L2920 pulsing
L7750 pulsing
L7310 pulsing
L7320 pulsing
L7630 pulsing
L7430 pulsing
L7560 not pulsing
L7520 pulsing
L7130 not pulsing
L3095 not pulsing
L7701 not pulsing


[B]Also check output rails from pages 57/58.[/B]
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R7829</RESISTOR> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> at <CAPACITOR>C7841</CAPACITOR> seems to be stable
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8155</RESISTOR> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR> stable
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0SW_AUDIO_HDA</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8041</RESISTOR> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8000</RESISTOR> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FET_R</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U8070</CHIP> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U8005</CHIP> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8011</RESISTOR> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0_FET_R</SIGNAL> at <CHIP>U8030</CHIP> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8050</RESISTOR> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R8081</RESISTOR> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0SW_PCH_HSIO</SIGNAL> at <TRANSISTOR>Q8060</TRANSISTOR> is pulsing
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> at <TRANSISTOR>Q8060</TRANSISTOR> is pulsing


[B]<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing too?[/B]
yes

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
Check for pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.
<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> pulsing too?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message: yes, pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> are pulsing

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Termination resistors and theyr traces.
Clean J6100 too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R6110</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6111</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6112</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6113</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6114</RESISTOR> --> 24.9 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6115</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6116</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6117</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6118</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6119</RESISTOR> --> 15 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6120</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6121</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6122</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6123</RESISTOR> --> 24.9 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6125</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6126</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6127</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6128</RESISTOR> --> 24.9 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6131</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6132</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm
<RESISTOR>R6133</RESISTOR> --> 43 Ohm

all resistors seem to be fine.

J6100 was very clean, nothing to do there.

But I have found something that looks like corrosion on <CHIP>U6101</CHIP>.
I have removed it with isopropyl alcohol. Still no fanspin.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
Add leaded solder on <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> pads and traces.
Be sure to get good contacts.
Change the chip if needed...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
[ATTACH type="full" width="187px" alt="20211022_105117.jpg"]60240[/ATTACH]

One pad was ripped of: <SIGNAL>SPIROM_USE_MLB</SIGNAL>. I have to recreate it.

And my fault: I have lost <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> and I can't find it... 🙈

<CHIP>U6101</CHIP> is called 74LVC1G99. It seems to be a 3-state gate in SOT833 package.

I have ordered them now. Keep you updated...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
Hi again,

changed <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> now. But still same issue.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message:
Be sure to have good solders and traces there.
Check continuity between pin 5 of <CHIP>U6101</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R1632</RESISTOR>.
Touch the pins directly when measure; not the pads from board.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) green/orange light, but no fan.
threads.message: Checked continuity. Seems to be good. But I will give up this device, it's too time consuming.
